alert.note: Alert for Blaine; Cascade; Chouteau; Glacier; Hill; Lewis and Clark; Liberty; Pondera; Teton; Toole (Montana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued June 17 at 3:14AM MDT by NWS GreatFalls
info.description: Flooding potential for the Rocky Mountain Front and North-central plains this weekend and early next week A Pacific weather system is expected to move through the Northern Rockies late this weekend into early next week, bringing potential river rises and flooding concerns over much of Central/North-central Montana. Precipitation will initially begin in the form of scattered showers and thunderstorms late Saturday through Sunday evening. Then steadier and more widespread rains will become established Sunday night through early Tuesday. Rainfall totals with this system appear to run in the 0.50 to 1.25 inch range for lower elevations, with 1 to 2 inches over higher terrain. Higher amounts are certainly possible, but confidence is low at this time. Warming temperatures, especially during the overnight hours, will speed up the mountain snow melt process, contributing additional water to creeks and rivers. The greatest potential for flooding from this event is along and near the Rocky Mountain Front, including the East Glacier area, but localized river rises will also be possible for other areas of Central and North-Central Montana. Fire burn scars in all areas will be monitored for potential debris/mud flows, should heavy rains move over them.
